cellular_pathogens.formula: Cellular pathogens (bacteria, fungi, parasites) have their own cellular machinery and can reproduce independently
cellular_pathogens.correct: Cellular pathogens possess ribosomes, enzymes, and metabolic pathways that allow independent reproduction

wrong.answer: Cellular pathogens require host cells to reproduce
wrong.error: Confusing cellular pathogens with non-cellular pathogens like viruses
wrong.fix: Cellular pathogens have complete cellular machinery for independent reproduction; viruses require host cells
wrong.action: Distinguish between cellular (independent) and non-cellular (host-dependent) pathogens

wrong.answer: Cellular pathogens lack ribosomes
wrong.error: Misunderstanding the cellular nature of these organisms
wrong.fix: All cellular pathogens have ribosomes for protein synthesis, though bacterial ribosomes differ from eukaryotic ones
wrong.action: Remember that 'cellular' means having cell structures including ribosomes

wrong.answer: Cellular pathogens cannot metabolise independently
wrong.error: Confusing obligate intracellular parasites with all cellular pathogens
wrong.fix: Most cellular pathogens have complete metabolic pathways; some are obligate intracellular but still cellular
wrong.action: Focus on the presence of cellular machinery, not lifestyle requirements

persistent.gap: Fundamental misunderstanding of cellular vs non-cellular pathogen classification
persistent.action: Review the defining features of cells: membrane, ribosomes, genetic material, metabolic enzymes

non_cellular_pathogens.formula: Non-cellular pathogens (viruses, prions) lack cellular machinery and require host cells for replication
non_cellular_pathogens.correct: Viruses need host ribosomes for protein synthesis; prions are misfolded proteins that cause other proteins to misfold

wrong.answer: Viruses have their own ribosomes for protein synthesis
wrong.error: Attributing cellular features to non-cellular pathogens
wrong.fix: Viruses lack ribosomes and must hijack host cell ribosomes to translate their genetic material
wrong.action: Remember viruses are genetic material in a protein coat - no cellular machinery

wrong.answer: Prions contain genetic material
wrong.error: Confusing prions with viruses or other pathogens
wrong.fix: Prions are purely protein - misfolded versions of normal cellular proteins with no nucleic acid
wrong.action: Prions are unique: protein-only infectious agents that cause conformational changes

wrong.answer: Non-cellular pathogens can reproduce outside host cells
wrong.error: Misunderstanding the host-dependency of non-cellular pathogens
wrong.fix: Without cellular machinery, viruses and prions cannot replicate independently
wrong.action: Non-cellular = no metabolism = must use host resources

persistent.gap: Confusion about what makes pathogens non-cellular and host-dependent
persistent.action: Compare virus structure (nucleic acid + capsid) with cell structure (membrane + organelles + metabolism)

virus_structure.formula: Viruses consist of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein capsid, with some having an envelope
virus_structure.correct: The viral genome may be single or double-stranded DNA or RNA; enveloped viruses have a lipid membrane from host cells

wrong.answer: All viruses contain DNA
wrong.error: Not recognising the diversity of viral genetic material
wrong.fix: Viruses can have DNA or RNA genomes, which can be single or double-stranded
wrong.action: Examples: influenza has RNA; herpes has DNA; COVID-19 has RNA

wrong.answer: The viral envelope is made by the virus itself
wrong.error: Misunderstanding envelope origin
wrong.fix: Enveloped viruses acquire their lipid envelope from host cell membranes during budding
wrong.action: The envelope contains host lipids with viral glycoproteins inserted

wrong.answer: The capsid is made of nucleic acid
wrong.error: Confusing capsid composition with viral genome
wrong.fix: The capsid is a protein coat that protects the nucleic acid genome inside
wrong.action: Capsid = protein shell; genome = nucleic acid inside

persistent.gap: Unclear understanding of basic virus structure and component origins
persistent.action: Draw and label a virus: genome (DNA/RNA) → capsid (protein) → envelope (host lipid + viral proteins)

viral_cycles.formula: Lytic cycle leads to immediate host cell destruction; lysogenic cycle involves viral DNA integration into host genome
viral_cycles.correct: In lysogenic cycle, viral DNA becomes a prophage and replicates with host DNA until triggered to enter lytic cycle

wrong.answer: Lysogenic cycle immediately destroys the host cell
wrong.error: Confusing lysogenic with lytic cycle
wrong.fix: Lysogenic cycle is dormant - viral DNA integrates and replicates passively with host; lytic causes destruction
wrong.action: Lysogenic = latent/hidden; Lytic = active/destructive

wrong.answer: Lytic cycle involves DNA integration into host genome
wrong.error: Mixing up the two viral reproductive strategies
wrong.fix: Lytic cycle: virus replicates immediately and lyses cell; no integration occurs
wrong.action: Lytic = lyse = burst; Lysogenic = lying dormant as prophage

wrong.answer: Prophage is found during the lytic cycle
wrong.error: Misplacing the prophage in the wrong cycle
wrong.fix: Prophage is integrated viral DNA during lysogenic cycle; lytic cycle has free viral DNA
wrong.action: Pro-phage = before active phage production; occurs in lysogenic phase

persistent.gap: Confusion between lytic and lysogenic reproductive strategies
persistent.action: Create comparison table: Lytic (immediate, destructive, new virions) vs Lysogenic (dormant, integrated, prophage)

prions.formula: Prions are misfolded proteins that cause normal proteins to adopt the abnormal conformation
prions.correct: Prion diseases are transmissible spongiform encephalopathies affecting brain tissue, causing neurodegeneration

wrong.answer: Prions can be destroyed by normal sterilisation
wrong.error: Underestimating prion resistance
wrong.fix: Prions are extremely resistant to heat, radiation, and chemicals that destroy nucleic acids
wrong.action: Prions require specialised decontamination (high-concentration bleach, prolonged autoclaving)

wrong.answer: Prions are a type of virus
wrong.error: Misclassifying prions with other pathogens
wrong.fix: Prions are purely protein with no genetic material; viruses have nucleic acid genomes
wrong.action: Prions are unique - infectious proteins that cause conformational disease

wrong.answer: Prion diseases are caused by foreign proteins entering the body
wrong.error: Misunderstanding prion origin
wrong.fix: Prions are misfolded versions of normal host proteins (PrP^C becomes PrP^Sc)
wrong.action: The body's own proteins misfold and cause a chain reaction

persistent.gap: Fundamental misunderstanding of prion nature and mechanism
persistent.action: Study prion mechanism: normal protein → contact with prion → conformational change → aggregation → neurodegeneration

self_markers.formula: MHC markers (self-antigens) on cell surfaces identify cells as belonging to the body
self_markers.correct: MHC class I is found on all nucleated cells; MHC class II is found on antigen-presenting cells

wrong.answer: Red blood cells have MHC class I markers
wrong.error: Forgetting that mature red blood cells lack nuclei
wrong.fix: Mature red blood cells are anucleate and lack MHC I; they have ABO antigens instead
wrong.action: MHC I on nucleated cells; red blood cells identified by blood group antigens

wrong.answer: All cells have MHC class II markers
wrong.error: Not distinguishing between MHC class I and II distribution
wrong.fix: MHC II is restricted to antigen-presenting cells (dendritic cells, macrophages, B cells)
wrong.action: MHC I = all nucleated cells; MHC II = APCs only

wrong.answer: MHC markers are the same in all individuals
wrong.error: Not recognising MHC polymorphism
wrong.fix: MHC genes are highly polymorphic - each person has unique combinations (except identical twins)
wrong.action: MHC uniqueness is why organ transplant matching is critical

persistent.gap: Confusion about MHC marker distribution and significance
persistent.action: Review: MHC I (all nucleated) presents internal antigens; MHC II (APCs only) presents external antigens

antigens.formula: Antigens are molecules that can be recognised by the immune system and trigger an immune response
antigens.correct: Epitopes are the specific regions of antigens that antibodies or T cell receptors bind to

wrong.answer: Antigens are always foreign molecules
wrong.error: Forgetting about self-antigens
wrong.fix: Antigens include both foreign molecules and self-antigens (MHC markers); immune system tolerates self
wrong.action: Antigen = any molecule recognised by immune system; foreign antigens trigger responses

wrong.answer: The entire antigen molecule binds to antibodies
wrong.error: Not understanding epitope specificity
wrong.fix: Only specific regions called epitopes bind to antibodies; one antigen may have multiple epitopes
wrong.action: Epitope = specific binding site; antigen = whole molecule with one or more epitopes

wrong.answer: Each antigen has only one epitope
wrong.error: Underestimating antigen complexity
wrong.fix: Large antigens typically have multiple epitopes, allowing binding by different antibodies
wrong.action: Multiple epitopes = stronger immune response through different antibody types

persistent.action: Visualise: antigen as a protein with multiple epitopes (binding sites) for different antibodies

allergens.formula: Allergens are normally harmless antigens that trigger inappropriate immune responses in sensitised individuals
allergens.correct: Allergic reactions involve IgE antibodies binding to mast cells, which degranulate releasing histamine

wrong.answer: Allergens are inherently harmful substances
wrong.error: Confusing allergens with toxins or pathogens
wrong.fix: Allergens (pollen, pet dander, foods) are harmless to most people; only cause reactions in sensitised individuals
wrong.action: Allergy = inappropriate immune response to harmless substance

wrong.answer: Allergic reactions occur on first exposure
wrong.error: Not understanding sensitisation requirement
wrong.fix: First exposure causes sensitisation (IgE production); subsequent exposures trigger the allergic response
wrong.action: Sensitisation → IgE binds to mast cells → re-exposure → degranulation → symptoms

wrong.answer: Allergic reactions are mediated by IgG antibodies
wrong.error: Confusing antibody classes
wrong.fix: Type I hypersensitivity (immediate allergy) is mediated by IgE, not IgG
wrong.action: IgE = allergy antibody; binds mast cells; triggers histamine release

persistent.action: Study allergy pathway: allergen → IgE production → IgE binds mast cells → re-exposure → degranulation → histamine → symptoms

rounds.title: Foundation
rounds.instructions: Master the basic definitions and structures of pathogens and immune recognition.

tabSections.title: Cellular vs Non-Cellular Pathogens
tabSections.instructions: Distinguish between cellular and non-cellular disease-causing agents.

sentences.text: Cellular pathogens include bacteria, fungi, and parasites, which can reproduce {{d1}} because they possess their own {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Think about whether they need a host cell to replicate

d2.tooltip: What structures do cells need to function independently?

sentences.text: Non-cellular pathogens such as {{d1}} lack ribosomes and therefore must hijack {{d2}} to produce viral proteins.

d1.tooltip: Which pathogen type is not made of cells?

d2.tooltip: Without ribosomes, what must viruses use for protein synthesis?

sentences.text: Unlike viruses, {{d1}} are purely protein with no genetic material, causing disease by inducing {{d2}} in normal proteins.

d1.tooltip: Which infectious agent contains only protein?

d2.tooltip: What do prions cause to happen to normal proteins?

tabSections.title: Virus Structure and Cycles
tabSections.instructions: Learn the components of viruses and their reproductive strategies.

d2.tooltip: Where does the viral envelope come from?

d1.tooltip: Which cycle involves dormant integration?

d2.tooltip: Which cycle destroys the host cell immediately?

tabSections.title: Self Recognition
tabSections.instructions: Understand how the immune system distinguishes self from non-self.

sentences.text: {{d1}} markers on cell surfaces identify cells as belonging to the body and are also called {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What are the major self-recognition molecules called?

d2.tooltip: MHC markers are antigens from the body itself

sentences.text: MHC class I is found on all {{d1}} cells, while MHC class II is restricted to {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Which cells have nuclei and therefore have MHC I?

d2.tooltip: Which specialised immune cells display MHC II?

sentences.text: Mature red blood cells lack {{d1}} and therefore do not express MHC markers, instead displaying {{d2}} antigens.

d1.tooltip: What do mature red blood cells lose?

d2.tooltip: What type of antigens identify red blood cell types?

tabSections.title: Antigens and Allergens
tabSections.instructions: Learn about immune recognition molecules and inappropriate responses.

sentences.text: An {{d1}} is any molecule that can be recognised by the immune system, with specific binding regions called {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What is the general term for molecules recognised by immunity?

d2.tooltip: What are the specific antibody-binding sites on antigens called?

sentences.text: Large antigens typically have {{d1}} epitopes, allowing recognition by {{d2}} different antibodies.

d1.tooltip: How many binding sites do large antigens usually have?

d2.tooltip: Can different antibodies bind the same antigen?

sentences.text: Allergens are {{d1}} substances that trigger inappropriate immune responses mediated by {{d2}} antibodies.

d1.tooltip: Are allergens inherently dangerous to everyone?

d2.tooltip: Which antibody class is involved in allergic reactions?

rounds.title: Application
rounds.instructions: Apply your understanding to explain pathogen mechanisms and immune recognition processes.

tabSections.title: Pathogen Characteristics
tabSections.instructions: Analyse the features that distinguish different pathogen types.

sentences.text: Bacteria are cellular pathogens that possess {{d1}} ribosomes, which differ from eukaryotic ribosomes and are targeted by {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What size are bacterial ribosomes?

d2.tooltip: What drugs target bacterial ribosomes?

sentences.text: Viruses cannot be treated with antibiotics because they lack {{d1}} and instead require {{d2}} medications.

d1.tooltip: What do antibiotics target that viruses lack?

d2.tooltip: What type of medication targets viruses?

sentences.text: Prion diseases are difficult to treat because prions resist {{d1}} and cause irreversible {{d2}} damage.

d1.tooltip: What process that kills other pathogens fails against prions?

d2.tooltip: Which body system do prion diseases primarily affect?

tabSections.title: Viral Mechanisms
tabSections.instructions: Understand how viruses infect and replicate within host cells.

sentences.text: Enveloped viruses are generally more susceptible to {{d1}} because their envelope is derived from {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What happens when lipid membranes dry out?

d2.tooltip: What is the viral envelope made from?

sentences.text: During the lysogenic cycle, the integrated viral DNA called a {{d1}} replicates passively when the {{d2}} divides.

d1.tooltip: What is integrated viral DNA called?

d2.tooltip: What replicates the prophage along with its own DNA?

sentences.text: Stress or immune suppression can trigger the prophage to exit the {{d1}} cycle and enter the {{d2}} cycle.

d1.tooltip: Which cycle has the dormant prophage?

d2.tooltip: Which cycle produces new viruses and destroys the cell?

tabSections.title: MHC Function
tabSections.instructions: Explain how MHC markers function in immune recognition.

sentences.text: MHC class I presents {{d1}} antigens from inside the cell, alerting {{d2}} T cells to infection.

d1.tooltip: Are these antigens from inside or outside the cell?

d2.tooltip: Which T cells respond to MHC I presentation?

sentences.text: MHC class II on antigen-presenting cells displays {{d1}} antigens that have been {{d2}} and processed.

d1.tooltip: Are these antigens from inside or outside the cell?

d2.tooltip: How do APCs acquire external antigens?

sentences.text: MHC polymorphism means each individual has {{d1}} MHC markers, which is why organ {{d2}} requires careful matching.

d1.tooltip: Are MHC markers the same in everyone?

d2.tooltip: What medical procedure requires MHC matching?

tabSections.title: Immune Recognition
tabSections.instructions: Analyse antigen-antibody interactions and allergic responses.

sentences.text: Antibodies bind to epitopes with high {{d1}}, meaning each antibody recognises only {{d2}} epitope shape.

d1.tooltip: What property describes precise molecular recognition?

d2.tooltip: How many epitope shapes can one antibody recognise?

sentences.text: During sensitisation to an allergen, {{d1}} antibodies are produced and bind to {{d2}} cells.

d1.tooltip: Which antibody class is involved in allergies?

d2.tooltip: Which cells have IgE receptors and release histamine?

sentences.text: On re-exposure, allergen binding to IgE causes mast cell {{d1}}, releasing {{d2}} and causing symptoms.

d1.tooltip: What do mast cells do when triggered by allergens?

d2.tooltip: What chemical causes allergic symptoms?

rounds.title: Synthesis
rounds.instructions: Integrate concepts to explain complex pathogen-immune interactions and clinical applications.

tabSections.title: Clinical Implications
tabSections.instructions: Connect pathogen biology to treatment and prevention strategies.

sentences.text: Antibiotics target {{d1}} features unique to bacteria, such as cell wall synthesis and {{d2}} ribosome function.

d1.tooltip: What type of machinery do antibiotics target?

d2.tooltip: What size ribosomes are found in bacteria?

sentences.text: Antiviral drugs often target viral {{d1}} or {{d2}} processes that are distinct from host cell functions.

d1.tooltip: What viral enzymes copy genetic material?

d2.tooltip: What process produces new viral genomes?

sentences.text: Prion diseases like {{d1}} cannot be cured because the misfolded proteins cause {{d2}} chain reactions in brain tissue.

d1.tooltip: Name a human prion disease

d2.tooltip: What type of change do prions induce in normal proteins?

tabSections.title: Viral Evolution and Disease
tabSections.instructions: Analyse how viral characteristics affect disease outcomes.

sentences.text: RNA viruses like {{d1}} mutate rapidly because RNA polymerase lacks {{d2}} activity.

d1.tooltip: Name a virus with an RNA genome that mutates frequently

d2.tooltip: What error-correcting mechanism do RNA polymerases lack?

sentences.text: Latent viral infections like {{d1}} persist because the virus remains in the {{d2}} cycle until reactivated.

d1.tooltip: Which virus causes recurring infections through latency?

d2.tooltip: Which cycle allows the virus to remain dormant?

sentences.text: Retroviruses like {{d1}} are particularly dangerous because they integrate into host {{d2}} permanently.

d1.tooltip: Which retrovirus causes AIDS?

d2.tooltip: What do retroviruses integrate their genome into?

tabSections.title: Clinical Applications of MHC
tabSections.instructions: Apply MHC understanding to transplantation and autoimmunity.

d1.tooltip: Which immune cells recognise MHC markers?

d2.tooltip: How do recipient cells perceive mismatched donor MHC?

d1.tooltip: What does the immune system normally tolerate?

d2.tooltip: What kind of tissue is damaged in autoimmunity?

d1.tooltip: What type of disease is linked to particular MHC variants?

d2.tooltip: What might be inappropriately presented, triggering autoimmunity?

tabSections.title: Immunological Applications
tabSections.instructions: Connect antigen concepts to vaccines and allergy treatment.

sentences.text: Vaccines work by presenting {{d1}} to the immune system, inducing production of {{d2}} cells without causing disease.

d1.tooltip: What immune-stimulating molecules do vaccines contain?

d2.tooltip: What type of immune cells provide long-term protection?

d1.tooltip: What is the patient gradually exposed to?

d2.tooltip: Which non-allergic antibody class blocks allergen binding?

d1.tooltip: What do mast cells do when extensively triggered?

d2.tooltip: What chemical causes anaphylactic symptoms?
